quote: Mind precedes all things; mind is their chief.
If one speaks or acts with a pure mind, happiness follows like a shadow.
Hatred is never appeased by hatred; by non‑hatred alone is hatred appeased.
He abused me, he struck me—such thoughts keep hatred alive.
He abused me, he struck me—abandoning such thoughts, hatred is quenched.
Like a storm the wind cannot shake a mountain, so blame does not shake the wise.
Just as a solid rock is not shaken by the storm, the wise are not moved by praise or blame.
As an irrigator guides water, a fletcher straightens an arrow, the wise shape themselves.
One truly is one’s own protector; who else could be?
Better than a thousand hollow words is a single word that brings peace.
Wakefulness is the path to the deathless; heedlessness is the path to death.
By effort and heedfulness, by self‑control and restraint, the wise make for an island no flood can overwhelm.
Conquer anger with non‑anger; conquer the miser with giving; conquer the liar with truth.
All tremble at violence; all fear death. Comparing oneself with others, one should not kill or cause to kill.
Not by silence does one become a sage if, confused and ignorant, one is still foolish.
Health is the greatest gift, contentment the greatest wealth, a trusted friend the best relative, Nibbāna the highest bliss.
Just as a bee gathers nectar and departs without harming the flower, so should the sage live.
If one holds oneself dear, one should guard oneself well.
Neither mother, father, nor any other kin can do as much good as a well‑directed mind.
Even the gods emulate the mindful one who is ever steadfast and pure.
There is no fire like lust, no grip like hatred, no net like delusion, no river like craving.
Victory breeds hatred; the defeated live in pain. Happily the peaceful live, giving up victory and defeat.
From craving springs grief; from craving springs fear. For one free of craving there is no grief—how then fear?
He who has conquered himself is a far greater hero than he who has conquered a thousand men in battle.
Not by matted hair, not by lineage, not by birth does one become a brahman; by truth and righteousness one becomes pure.
The gift of Dhamma surpasses all gifts; the taste of Dhamma surpasses all tastes.
By oneself is evil done; by oneself one is defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself one is purified.
As rain breaks through a poorly thatched hut, so passion enters an undeveloped mind.
As rain does not penetrate a well‑thatched house, passion does not enter a well‑developed mind.
Speak only the speech that does not bring remorse and is welcomed by the wise.
If one finds a prudent companion, let one go with him joyfully and mindfully; if not, walk alone like a king who has left a conquered kingdom.
A fool sleeps as if already dead; but the master is awake and lives forever.
Do not consider little faults as trivial; a jar is filled by falling drops.
If one commits no wrong with body, speech, or mind, one has nothing to fear.
All conditioned things are impermanent—when one sees this with wisdom, one turns away from suffering.
All conditioned things are suffering—when one sees this with wisdom, one turns away from suffering.
All phenomena are not‑self—when one sees this with wisdom, one turns away from suffering.
One should not harm living beings; one should not speak harshly; restraining oneself from killing and speaking truthfully, one should be moderate in food.
To avoid all evil, to cultivate good, to purify one’s mind—this is the teaching of the Buddhas.
Enduring patience is the highest austerity; Nibbāna is the supreme, say the Buddhas.
Like a fish drawn from its watery home, thrown on land, the mind trembles, trying to escape the realm of Māra.
Difficult is it to find a noble friend; difficult to dwell delighted in seclusion; difficult to bear the faults of others.
He who delights in the Dhamma dwells in happiness with a tranquil mind.
One is not a wise man because he speaks much; he who is loving, without hate, fearful, or fearless—he is called wise.
Better it is to live alone; there is no companionship with a fool.
The fragrant odors of sandalwood and tagara travel not against the wind; the scent of the virtuous spreads in all directions.
Few are those who reach the far shore; most people run up and down on this shore.
Not by rituals and vows, nor by much learning, does one attain peace; but by freedom from lust, hatred, and delusion.
If, like a broken gong, you are silent, you have come to Nibbāna; for no anger is found in you.
It is easy to see the faults of others, hard to see one’s own.
As the jasmine sheds its withered flowers, so should one shed passion and hatred.
The wise abandon the unwholesome and cultivate the wholesome, watching over their minds.
There is no path in the sky; there is no true ascetic outside the Dhamma.
Even if for a lifetime the fool associates with the wise, he no more knows the Dhamma than a spoon knows the taste of soup.
Like a beautiful flower, full of color but without scent, is a well‑spoken word that is not acted upon.
A tamed mind brings happiness.
Whatever harm an enemy might do to an enemy, a wrongly directed mind can do worse to oneself.
Guard your mind well; a guarded mind brings happiness.
If you see a wise person who points out your faults and corrects you, associate with them as with a revealer of treasure.
One should speak the truth, not be angry, and, when asked, give, even to the least.
Hunger is the worst illness; conditioned existence the worst suffering. Knowing this as it really is, the wise realize Nibbāna, the highest bliss.
A man is not a true monk if he harms others; one who harms none is called a monk.
Abandon anger; discard pride; overcome all fetters. Suffering does not befall one who is passionless and attached to nothing.
The careless are dead already; the heedful are fully alive.
Do not neglect your own welfare for the sake of another’s, however great; clearly knowing your own good, pursue the true goal.
Just as rust eats the iron from which it is produced, so do one’s own deeds lead the negligent to a state of woe.
A single day lived with virtue and meditation is better than a hundred years lived in idleness and laxity.
The wise are intent on absorption; they delight in the peace of renunciation.
Few are those who see clearly; many do not.
If a man does what he should not, he does it to his own loss.
Even as a mother protects with her life her only child, so with a boundless heart should one cherish all living beings.
Let none deceive another or despise anyone anywhere.
Contentment is the greatest wealth; few desires, the best riches.
Not by water are stains removed; only by inner truth is one purified.
Harmlessness to all beings—this is the highest blessing.
Bhikkhus, I say that intention is kamma.
Whatever one frequently thinks and ponders upon, that will become the inclination of the mind.
All conditioned things are impermanent—when one sees this with wisdom, one grows disenchanted with suffering; this is the path to purity.
What is impermanent is suffering; what is suffering is non‑self; what is non‑self should be seen as it really is with correct wisdom.
This is suffering; this is the origin of suffering; this is the cessation of suffering; this is the path leading to the cessation of suffering.
Whatever is subject to arising is all subject to cessation.
With the destruction of craving comes the destruction of suffering.
Not by mere vows and austerities, not by much learning, does one attain peace; only by the complete ending of lust.
A tamed mind brings happiness like a cool lake in summer.
Just as the ocean has but one taste, the taste of salt, so too this Dhamma‑Vinaya has but one taste, the taste of liberation.
By protecting oneself, one protects others; by protecting others, one protects oneself.
When a wise person does no evil with body, speech, or mind, he experiences happiness.
When greed, hate, and delusion are abandoned, the mind becomes pliant, malleable, and bright.
Monks, develop mindfulness of breathing; when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated, it is of great fruit and great benefit.
In whatsoever Dhamma and Discipline the noble eightfold path is found, there is the true ascetic.
There is the case where a bhikkhu contemplates the body in the body—ardent, fully aware, and mindful.
Not to do any evil, to cultivate the good, to purify one’s mind—this is the instruction of the Buddhas.
By knowing and seeing as they are the five aggregates, one becomes disenchanted and dispassionate.
He who sees dependent origination sees the Dhamma; he who sees the Dhamma sees dependent origination.
Monks, this mind is radiant, but it is defiled by adventitious defilements.
source: Aṅguttara Nikāya 1.49–52 (often cited with MN context)

quote: Whatever is felt is included in suffering.
Do not go by reports, by legends, by traditions, by scripture… When you know for yourselves that these things are unwholesome, abandon them.
There are these three roots of the unwholesome: greed, hatred, and delusion.
There are these three roots of the wholesome: non‑greed, non‑hatred, and non‑delusion.
There are these four right efforts: to prevent, to abandon, to develop, to maintain.
These four ways of dealing with others: giving, kindly speech, beneficial conduct, impartiality.
There are these five obstacles: sensual desire, ill will, dullness‑drowsiness, restlessness‑remorse, and doubt.
These five precepts lead to welfare and happiness for long time.
Associate with the wise; avoid the foolish; honor the honorable.
There are these six recollections: the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Saṅgha, virtue, generosity, and the devas.
The Dhamma is visible here and now, timeless, inviting inspection, leading onward, to be experienced individually by the wise.
There is, monks, an unborn, unbecome, unmade, uncompounded. Were there not, no escape from the born, become, made, compounded would be discerned.
With the change of conditions there is change of elements.
Just as a flame is blown out by the wind, so the mind is calmed by the rightly developed path.
Whatever is subject to arising is subject to cessation—having known this, the Tathāgata teaches the Dhamma.
Give, monks, for giving is praised; the gift of Dhamma surpasses all gifts.
As a border town well guarded within and without, so guard yourself.
Do not give your mind to the delights of others; rather, guard your own well‑being.
If while on the way you meet no one your equal or better, travel alone.
The wise do not hurt others; they are restrained by virtue and freed by wisdom.
A single day lived seeing the arising and passing of things is better than a hundred years not seeing this.
One should not disregard one’s own welfare for another’s, however great.
From wholesome conduct comes happiness; from unwholesome, suffering.
Not by birth is one an outcast; by deeds one is an outcast.
The wise, ever meditative, do not delight in sense pleasures.
Whoever destroys life, speaks false, takes what is not given, goes to another’s partner, and indulges in intoxicants digs up his own root.
Restraint in body is good; restraint in speech is good; restraint in mind is good; restraint everywhere is good.
Few cross to the far shore; the rest only run up and down the bank.
The wise are tranquil, without attachment, having understood the true path.
There is no satisfying sensual desires, even with a shower of gold.
Better than lordship over the earth is going to the refuge of the Buddha.
Who sees the Dhamma sees me; who sees me sees the Dhamma.
Monks, abandon what is unwholesome; it is possible to abandon the unwholesome.
Guarding the sense‑doors, moderate in eating, devoted to wakefulness—this is the path to peace.
Whatever ascetics or brahmans remember their past lives, all do so through mindfulness and clear comprehension.
In this very fathom‑long body are the world, the origin of the world, the cessation of the world, and the way leading to the cessation of the world.
